title: B-Sens name Driedger goalie for Saturday's AHL opener
text:
B-Sens name Driedger goalie for Saturday's AHL opener Matt Weinstein, mweinstein@gannett.com | @SteinTime44 4:04 p.m. EDT October 9, 2015 The preseason work is over, the rosters are set and the 2015-16 American Hockey League season is underway. Rochester's Allan McPherson can't reach a loose rebound before Binghamton goalie Chris Driedger as he's run off the play by Spencer Humphries in the first period during their preseason game played at RIT's Gene Polisseni Center Thursday, Oct. 1, 2015. (Photo: SHAWN DOWD/@sdowdphoto/, STAFF PHOTOGRAPHER) Story Highlights The B-Sens begin the 2015-16 regular season Saturday against Albany at home AHL standings and playoff positioning this season is determined by points percentage 1 CONNECT 4 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
The preseason work is over, the rosters are set and the 2015-16 American Hockey League season is underway. 
The Binghamton Senators begin their regular-season campaign Saturday night when they host the Albany Devils at the Floyd L. Maines Veterans Memorial Arena. 
B-Sens coach Luke Richardson has yet to announce captains for the contest, but he has named a starting goaltender. Chris Driedger, who was a third-round pick in 2012 by Ottawa and is starting his second professional season, will get the nod with Scott Greenham serving as backup. Driedger started the past season playing for Evansville of the ECHL and completed the rare feat of also appearing in the AHL and National Hockey League in his first pro season. 
Driedger finished with a 6-0-0 record in eight games with the B-Sens last season, compiling a 2.55 goals-against average and .923 save percentage. The 21-year-old from Winnipeg also had an 8-27-4 record with a 3.78 GAA and .885 save percentage in 40 games with Evansville last season. He did not allow a goal in 23 minutes of NHL action last season while appearing in one game. 
Slight standings change 
There is a decidedly new look to the AHL for its 80th season. 
Five Western Conference NHL teams have moved their affiliates to California, giving the AHL its first-ever presence in the Golden State. The Bakersfield Condors (top affiliate of the Edmonton Oilers), Ontario Reign (Los Angeles Kings), San Diego Gulls (Anaheim Ducks), San Jose Barracuda (San Jose Sharks) and Stockton Heat (Calgary Flames) are all members of the Pacific Division this fall. 
The AHL is also returning to Winnipeg in 2015-16 with the return of the Manitoba Moose as the top affiliate of the NHL’s Jets. The Moose spent 10 seasons in the AHL from 2001 to 2011. 
Other affiliation shuffles heading into the new season have resulted in new parent clubs for the St. John’s IceCaps (Montreal Canadiens), Lake Erie Monsters (Columbus Blue Jackets), Springfield Falcons (Arizona Coyotes), San Antonio Rampage (Colorado Avalanche) and Portland Pirates (Florida Panthers). 
The league’s alignment underwent a change as well, with the league splitting into four divisions – the Atlantic and the North in the Eastern Conference and the Central and the Pacific in the Western Conference. Teams will play a 76-game schedule with the exception of the five California-based teams, who will play 68 games apiece. 
Standings order will now be determined by points percentage, not total points. 
New rules 
The 2015-16 season will feature some new rules, most notably a five-minute overtime period during the regular season played at three skaters aside for the duration. 
Last season, playing a combination of 4-on-4 and 3-on-3 during a seven-minute overtime, the AHL saw 201 of its 268 OT games (75.0 percent) decided in the extra session – a dramatic increase from 2013-14, when 35.3 percent of OT games were decided during the 4-on-4 period used that season. 
Two other rules to watch for: Rule 79.4: “Video Review – Coaches Challenge” permits a team – if it has its timeout available – to request a video review of any situation that would normally be subject to official review under Rule 79.3. If the challenge is successful, the team retains its timeout. Rule 76.4: “Face-Offs” calls for the defending player to place his stick on the ice first for all face-offs except those at center ice, where the visiting player will place his stick on the ice first. 
HOCKEY NIGHT 
WHO: Albany Devils at Binghamton Senators 
WHEN: 7:10 p.m./Saturday 
WHERE: Floyd L. Maines Veterans Memorial Arena 
RADIO: WINR-FM (96.9) 
TICKETS: $20 for side seating ($21 on game day), $19 for end seating ($20 on game day), $2 discount for youths under 12. Call 607-722-7367, visit the Arena box office or go to www.ticketmaster.com. 
PROMOTIONS: Pregame “Party on the Deck” starts at 5:30 p.m. outside the Arena’s second-level with a DJ, inflatable kids games from Taylor Rental, and video game station from Gametime Express. … All fans receive a free B-Sens magnet schedule courtesy of the Binghamton Hockey Booster Club. … Donate new, packaged socks to the Rescue Mission’s table on the concourse for a special discount coupon for an upcoming B-Sens game. 1 CONNECT 4 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://press.sn/1RyyQJW TOP VIDEOS
